wfo-0001025872	distribution	"<p>On the western slopes of the Andes in the department of Lima, Peru, from 2500 to 3500 m.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-amblophyllum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	e9efe506-e0a8-44c3-a398-71e128c12d63#distribution	0afae86f-5ec8-4d1e-b45e-90310196adec
wfo-0001025872	general	"Dense shrubs 1-2 m tall; young stems and leaves densely red-papillose, the papillae ca. 0.1 mm long; older stems glabrous; bark of older stems dark grayish-brown.<br/>Sympodial units plurifoliate.<br/>Leaves narrowly elliptic, coriaceous, crinkled and glabrous above in dry specimens, densely pubescent along the midrib beneath, the trichomes uniseriate, simple, 0.5-1 mm long, crowded at the junctions of the midrib and the main lateral veins, leaf margins revolute, blades 4.5-13 x 1.7-3 cm, with 6-10 pairs of main lateral veins, these not visible above, prominent beneath, the apex rounded, the base acute, decurrent onto the petiole; petioles 0.6-1 cm long.<br/>Inflorescences terminal, later becoming lateral, occasionally opposite the leaves, branched several times, 2-5 cm long, 10-25-flowered, but with only a few flowers at a time, glabrous or glandular-resinous; pedicel scars irregularly spaced 1-2 mm apart, beginning ca. 1 cm from the base of the inflorescence. Buds flattened apically when young, later globose, the corolla soon exserted from the calyx tube. Pedicels at anthesis deflexed, thick and fleshy, 1-2 cm long, tapering from the base of the calyx tube to a base 1 mm in diam.<br/>Flowers with the calyx tube broadly cup-shaped, ca. 1.5 mm long, the lobes rounded-triangular, often auriculate, 1-1.5 mm long, the margins thickened and paler, glabrous; corolla white, fleshy, 1.2-1.6 cm in diam., lobed 2/3 of the way to the base, the lobes planar at anthesis, the tips and margins of the lobes densely papillose; anthers 4-4.5 x 1-1.5 mm, poricidal at the tips, the terminal 0.5 mm thickened and paler, the pores tear-drop shaped; free portion of the filaments 0.25-0.5 mm long, the filament tube ca. 0.5 mm long; ovary glabrous; style straight, 6-8 mm long; stigma capitate, bright green in live plants, the surface minutely papillose.<br/>Fruit a globose, green berry, 1-1.3 cm in diam.; fruiting pedicels woody and deflexed, 1.2-1.5 cm long, ca. 1.5 mm in diam. at the base.<br/>Seeds dark brownish in dry material, greenish-tan in live plants, flattened-reniform, 3.5-4 x 2-2.5 mm, the margins incrassate and somewhat paler, the surfaces deeply pitted."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-amblophyllum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	e9efe506-e0a8-44c3-a398-71e128c12d63#general	0afae86f-5ec8-4d1e-b45e-90310196adec
wfo-0001026325	conservation	"<p>Solanum aridum is distributed over a large area in Argentina, Bolivia, and Paraguay with a calculated extent of occurrence of ca. 1 × 106 km<sup>2</sup> and an area of occupancy of 1,376 km<sup>2</sup>. It is common throughout its range and typically grows in disturbed areas, and there is no evidence that the size of its populations or number of locations are declining. Solanum aridum is therefore assigned a preliminary conservation status of ""least concern"" (LC).</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-aridum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	c27a005c-bb84-4ea4-9701-bb50424c4552#conservation	0b3104fd-868b-40c9-b178-400dad76bcd3
wfo-0001026325	distribution	"<p>Solanum aridum occurs in northern and central Argentina, eastern Bolivia, and western Paraguay. It typically grows in disturbed areas such as roadsides and waste areas, often in sandy or clay soils. Most specimens examined occur at elevations between 300–1,200 m, but one sheet (C. Peláez 308) reported an elevation of 2,025 m.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-aridum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	c27a005c-bb84-4ea4-9701-bb50424c4552#distribution	0b3104fd-868b-40c9-b178-400dad76bcd3
wfo-0001026325	general	"Upright perennial herb up to 0.5 m tall; stems simple or few-branched; roots producing buds and tuber-like ellipsoid swellings ca. 1–3 × 1 cm. Stems sparsely to densely pubescent with sessile stellate hairs 0.15–0.4 mm in diameter, with 4–8 lateral rays, the central ray absent or up to 0.3 mm long, unarmed or very sparsely armed with straight tapered prickles up to 3.5 mm long. <br/>Sympodial units 2- to 3-foliate when more than one inflorescence per shoot, but often only one formed and then appearing plurifoliate, the leaves not geminate.<br/>Leaves simple, the blades 2–10 × 1–5 cm, ovate-elliptic, elliptic, or oblong in outline, discolorous, densely stellate-pubescent abaxially, less densely so adaxially with hairs like those of the stems, unarmed or sparsely armed with prickles up to 3.3(5) mm long on the major veins abaxially and adaxially; base cuneate to subtruncate; margin subentire, sinuate or shallowly lobed with 2–6 lobes per side; apex obtuse to acute; petioles 0.5–5 cm long, densely stellate-pubescent, unarmed or sparsely armed with prickles up to 4 mm long. <br/>Inflorescences 1–2.5 cm long, extra-axillary, unbranched or forked, with 1–6 flowers, weakly andromonoecious with the proximal flowers hermaphroditic and the distal flowers staminate, the axes moderately to densely stellate-pubescent, unarmed or very sparsely armed with prickles up to 3 mm long; peduncle up to 2 cm long or absent, with the lowermost flower(s) emerging directly from the node; pedicels 1–2(3) cm long in flower, 2–4 cm long and curved downward in fruit, spaced 0.5–1.5 cm apart, articulated at the base, moderately to densely stellate-pubescent, unarmed or very sparsely armed with prickles up to 1.5 mm long. <br/>Flowers 5-merous, heteromorphic, short-styled and functionally malae and long-stuled hermaphorditic. Calyx 7–10 mm long, the tube 2.5–4 mm long, the lobes 4–7 × 1.8–2.5 mm, linear to lanceolate, often unequal, the apex caudate to acuminate, densely stellate-pubescent abaxially, glabrous adaxially, unarmed or very sparsely armed abaxially with prickles up to 3 mm long; fruiting calyx somewhat accrescent but not completely covering the fruit, 10–20 mm long, the tube 2–4 mm long, the lobes 6.5–15 × 2–5 mm, narrowly triangular, moderately stellate-pubescent, unarmed or very sparsely armed with prickles up to 3.5 mm long. Corollas 1.7–3.5 cm in diameter, 12–16 mm long, stellate to stellate-pentagonal or rotate-stellate, chartaceous, usually white, sometimes pale blue-violet, the tube 2–6 mm long, the lobes 5–9 × 4–8 mm, deltate to triangular, the apex acute, densely stellate-pubescent abaxially, glabrous adaxially. Stamens with filaments 0.6–1.8 × ca. 0.2 mm; anthers 7–8.5 × 1.2–2 mm, narrowly lanceolate, somewhat connivent, yellow, the pores directed distally. Ovary 1.3–2.5 × 1.2–2.5 mm, subglobose-ovoid, glabrous; style 10–12 × 1–1.5 mm, cylindrical, straight, glabrous, exserted in hermaphroditic flowers; stigma capitate. <br/>Fruit an ellipsoid to ovoid berry, 1.2–2.2 × 1.2–1.8 cm, the apex obtuse to somewhat pointed, light green with darker green mottling when young, yellow or pale yellow to yellow-orange at maturity, glabrous, the rind tough. <br/>Seeds 1.5–2.3 × 1.1–2 mm, flattened-reniform, lenticular, yellow, the surface finely foveolate."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-aridum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	c27a005c-bb84-4ea4-9701-bb50424c4552#general	0b3104fd-868b-40c9-b178-400dad76bcd3
wfo-0001026325	use	"<p>Matesevach (2002) and Barboza (2013) report several common names from Argentina: comida de víbora, meloncillo, melon del campo, and pocotillo. Two specimens from Bolivia, G. Bourdy 2082 and R. de Michel et al. 2539, collected in Cordillera Province in Santa Cruz Department, recorded the names tutia and tutiami, respectively. Label information from G. Bourdy 2082 states that the fruit was ground and used to treat scabies. The name tutia very likely refers to the ellipsoid tuber-like swellings on the roots, a name similar to tutía-tutía, which was applied to S. hieronymi, another species with root swellings.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-aridum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Use	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	c27a005c-bb84-4ea4-9701-bb50424c4552#use	0b3104fd-868b-40c9-b178-400dad76bcd3
wfo-0001030492	distribution	"<p>Secondary growth, disturbed areas and clearings in oak forest and montane wet forest in Costa Rica and Panama between 900-2200 m in elevation.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-pluviale		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	879b8108-13fb-40a3-9d19-c4a89083206a#distribution	0b9b859c-c0fb-4cb1-bb60-ca8beaa451c0
wfo-0001030492	general	"Shrub or small tree 1.5-6 m tall. Flowering stems glabrous to sparsely ferruginous-pubescent with sessile to short-stalked stellate hairs ca. 1 mm in diameter, the stalks up to ca. 1 mm long, with very short eglandular midpoints ca. 0.1 mm long and 4-8 lateral rays 0.3-0.5 mm long, the youngest parts also with scattered, nearly sessile glands, sparsely but coarsely armed with broad-based, straight to somewhat recurved, yellowish or brown prickles 0.5-1 cm long.<br/>Sympodial units difoliate, geminate.<br/>Leaves simple, the blades 10-35+ x 5-30+ cm, ca. 1-2 times as long as wide, more or less uniform in size and shape, but younger plants or sprouts with much larger and more deeply lobed leaves (to 30-40+ x 25-50+ cm, often divided more than halfway to midrib into 5-6 pairs of lobes), elliptic to ovate, chartaceous, sparsely to moderately pubescent adaxially with ferruginous sessile stellae ca. 0.5 mm in diameter, with eglandular midpoints 0.1-0.5 mm long and shorter than to somewhat longer than the lateral rays, the lateral rays mostly 4, more sparsely stellate-pubescent abaxially with hairs similar to the upper surface but up to 1 mm in diameter and less rusty, with short midpoints, and with somewhat longer rays, unarmed or with a few coarse broad-based prickles on the midrib or major lateral veins; base truncate to subcordate, sometimes oblique; margin entire to coarsely toothed or pinnatifid; apex acute; petioles 3-8 cm (to over 10 cm in juvenile leaves), glabrous or sparsely pubescent with hairs like those of the stem, often armed with a few coarse prickles like those of the stem.<br/>Inflorescence 3-10 cm, extra-axillary, unbranched, forked, or further branched, with 10-50+ flowers, most flowers apparently perfect but some female-sterile, the axes moderately to densely ferruginous-pubescent with sessile or short-stalked stellae ca. 1 mm in diameter, the stalks up to 1.5 mm long, with long or short (0.1-1 mm), occasionally glandular midpoints and 4-7 lateral rays ca. 0.5 mm long, unarmed; peduncle 1-1.5 cm; rachis 1-8 cm; pedicels 3-10 mm in flower, 15-20 mm and erect and often somewhat woody in fruit, spaced 2-5 mm apart, articulated at the base.<br/>Flowers with the calyx 4-8 mm long, the tube 2-4 mm, the lobes 4-6 x 2 mm, caudate-acuminate at tips, at first with the margin more or less truncate with the narrow lobe tips emerging, later splitting at the sinuses into more or less rectangular lobes with caudate-acuminate tips, moderately to densely ferruginous-pubescent; fruiting calyx slightly accrescent, the lobes 4-6 x 3-5 mm, not covering the fruit. Corolla 2-3 cm in diameter, 12-25 mm long, stellate, chartaceous, white, the tube ca. 4 mm, the lobes 7-18 x 3-7 mm, lanceolate, with sparse interpetalar tissue, acute at apices, sparsely to densely stellate-pubescent abaxially, glabrous or sparsely pubescent on midvein adaxially. Stamens with the filaments 2-2.5 mm; anthers 5-7 x 1.5-2 mm, tapered, connivent, yellow, the pores small and directed distally. Ovary glandular-puberulent; style 9-11 x 0.25-0.5 mm in perfect flowers, cylindrical, straight, glabrous or sparsely glandular near base; stigma capitate.<br/>Fruits 1-1.5 cm in diameter, globose, green (perhaps not fully ripe?), glabrous at maturity, held upright.<br/>Seeds 2-3 x 2 mm, flattened, yellowish to light brown, the surface minutely pitted."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-pluviale		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	879b8108-13fb-40a3-9d19-c4a89083206a#general	0b9b859c-c0fb-4cb1-bb60-ca8beaa451c0

wfo-0001028736	general	"Shrub 1-2 m, occasionally scandent. Stems moderately armed with recurved, yellow to green roselike prickles, these 3-8 mm in length, the base 2-4 x 0.5-2 mm, moderately to densely pubescent with white, porrect-stellate hairs, the stalks nearly absent to 1 mm, multiseriate, the rays 6-8, 0.5-1mm, unicellular to multicellular, the midpoints absent to 1 mm. <br/>Sympodial units difoliate, the leaves geminate, those of a pair unequal. <br/>Leaves simple, the blades 6-13x3-8 cm, rhombic, unlobed to 2-5 lobes per side, the sinuses cut less than 1/6 of the way to the midvein, the lobes obtuse, leaves chartaceous, slightly discolorous, dark green adaxially, light green abaxially, with both leaf surfaces sparsely to moderately pubescent with stellate hairs like those of the stem; major veins 3-6 on either side of the midvein, the midrib abaxially unarmed or with occasional prickles like those of the stem; base acute, decurrent onto petiole; apex acute to obtuse; petioles absent to 1 cm, moderately pubescent with hairs like those of the stem, unarmed or occasionally armed with prickles like those of the stem.<br/>Inflorescences 1-3 cm, extra-axillary, unbranched, with 5-15 flowers, apparently all perfect, the axes moderately to densely pubescent with hairs like those of the stem but with the stalks to 1.5 mm, unarmed; peduncle absent to 0.5 cm; rachis 1-3 cm; pedicels 5-10 mm in flower, 10-15 mm in fruit, filiform, nearly contiguous, spaced 0.5-1.5 mm apart. <br/>Flowers apparently all perfect, 5-merous. Corolla 1-2 cm in diameter, chartaceous, white to yellow-white, stellate, lobed nearly to the base, the lobes 4-6 x 1.5-3 mm, narrowly triangular, sparsely pubescent abaxially with hairs like those of the stem with midpoints either absent or to 1 mm, midpoints either white or occasionally purple, glabrous adaxially. Stamens 4-6 mm; filaments up to 1 mm, glabrous; anthers 3.5-5 x 1-2 mm, attenuate, tapering, connivent, yellow, the base cordate, the apex obtuse, the pores apical, directed introsely. Ovary very sparsely pubescent with multicellular, uniseriate glandular hairs 0.2-0.4 mm long; style 4-6 x 0.5-1.5 mm, exserted beyond stamens, cylindrical, white, sparsely pubescent with stellate hairs like those of the stem; stigma up to 1 mm wide, cylindrical, green. <br/>Fruit a thin-skinned berry, 4-12 mm in diameter, globose, mottled green when immature, mottled orange or red when mature, glabrous. <br/>Seeds 40-70 per fruit, 1-1.5 x 0.5-1 mm, reniform, brown, flattened, the surface netlike with many pits created by small raised ridges."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-jamaicense		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	a1c94cef-ac5a-47b0-ab2b-8017cb05f8c2#general	0baba61e-0c6d-46a1-ba76-f8eb2a444b66

wfo-0001028046	general	"Shrub 2-3 m tall, lightly armed; stems erect or subscandent, sparsely prickly, the prickles 0.3-0.5 cm, yellow, compressed and stellate pubescent at the base, pubescence of prominent rusty red stalked porrect stellate trichomes with a unicellular midpoint; new growth densely rusty red pubescent; bark of older stems dark-brown or grayish brown with sparse stellate trichomes.<br/>Sympodial units difoliate.<br/>Leaves simple, 13-38 x 5-18 cm, elliptic to obovate, chartaceous, the upper surfaces subhirsute, rusty-red, the trichomes sessile to subsessile, porrect stellate with a multicellular midpoint and reduced rays ca. ¼ the length of the midpoint, mixed with minute simple glandular trichomes, the lower surfaces densely tomentose, the trichomes rigid, stalked, multangulate with 1-multicellular midpoints; base acute and attenuate, decurrent on the petiole; margins entire; apex acute to acuminate; petioles 1-7 cm, somewhat winged, occasionally with yellow prickles 0.2-0.3 cm, pubescent like the stems.<br/>Inflorescences opposite the leaves, 3-12 cm long, simple, with approximately 20 flowers, densely rusty-red pubescent like the stems with porrect stellate trichomes; peduncle 4-5 cm, unarmed, rusty red pubescent; pedicels 0.5-1 cm, cylindrical, pubescent like the rest of the inflorescence, but the pubescence denser, articulated at the base; pedicel scars unevenly spaced, slightly raised. wfo-0001028370	general	"Prickly, taprooted, spreadingly branched, annual herbs, 3-7 dm high; stems terete, green, prickly, densely or sparsely viscid with gland-tipped, simple hairs 0.2-0.4 mm long; prickles subulate to acicular, 2-8 mm, if subulate then broad based.<br/>Sympodial untis usually difoliate, somewhat geminate.<br/>Leaves broadly ovate to deltoid, twice pinnatifid, usually pinnatisect near the base, with obtuse or rounded ultimate lobes; blades 4-11 cm long, prickly along the main veins, variously glandular above and often with a few strait, simple, eglandular hairs to 0.8 mm long, beneath with scattered, sessile, few-rayed stellae and short-stipitate glands; petioles armed, 1/2-2/3 as long as the blades.<br/>Inflorescences internodal, 4-10 cm long when fully extended, 5-9-flowered.<br/>Mature buds obovoid, ca. 1 cm long. Calyx at anthesis divided ca. 2/3 to the base into lanceolate lobes, tube campanulate, 1.5-2.2 mm long. Corolla violet or blue, 1.0-1.7 cm across, pentagonal, the lobes narrowly to broadly deltoid, the interpetalar tissue usually ample and plicate. Stamens with the anthers oblong, not markedly attenuate, the long one hardly distinct, 3.5-5.0 mm long, only the terminal m slightly incurved, purple-tinged; short anthers yellow, 2-4 mm long. Ovary glabrous, tightly invested in the developing calyx tube. Style 3-5 mm, slender. Stigma capitate, .3-0.6 mm across.<br/>Fruit a spherical berry, 9-12 mm in diam., dry and splitting at maturity, the surrounding, accrescent calyx tube coarsely prickly;<br/>Seeds 40-70 per berry, dark brown, lenticular, 2.5-2.9 mm long, minutely foveolate, variously ridged."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-heterodoxum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	1ac9df9a-7bb3-4d1e-8721-53571a80c595#general	0cb6ff0c-57ba-49bc-8f81-763a7aafc2b3

wfo-0001030342	general	"Herbaceous vine, terrestrial. Stems slender, glabrous or rarely pubescent with slender trichomes 0.8–1.5 m long. <br/>Sympodial units plurifoliate. <br/>Leaves 3-pinnate, the blades 1.5–7.5 x 1–7 cm, about as long as wide, membranous to chartaceous, glabrous adaxially or with widely scattered to dense, wide-diameter trichomes, 0.3–1.2 x 0.1–0.2 mm on the leaf blade, with trichomes like those of the stem more abundant along veins, glabrous abaxially, the margins entire to undulate, minutely revolute on some leaves, the rachis glabrous; lateral leaflets 0.5–5 x 1–5.5 cm, elliptical to rounded, the base oblique, cuneate to cordate on the proximal side, the apex obtuse to acuminate, the petiolules 0.5–3 mm, glabrous; apical leaflet 0.8–4 x 1–6 cm, broadly elliptical to rhomboid, the base cuneate, the apex obtuse to acute, apiculate, the petiolule 1-5 mm, glabrous; petioles 1.5–13 cm, sparsely sand-punctate, glabrous or rarely pubescent. wfo-0001028513	general	"Large, sparsely armed, lignescent perennials or small trees, 2-5 m tall. Stems stellate-pubescent with closely spaced sessile or short-stalked stellae with short midpoints, the stalks 0-0.4 (-0.7) mm long, the lateral rays 5-9, usually oriented in a horizontal plane, appressed in sessile stellae, 0.3-0.5 (-0.8) mm long, the midpoints ca. 1/3 the length of the lateral rays; cauline prickles scattered, often small, 1-3 (-6) mm long, weakly recurved; the larger prickles broad-based and laterally compressed.<br/>Sympodial units 2-foliate, geminate.<br/>Leaves simple, the blades 25-45 x 20-35 cm, ca. 1.1-1.3 times as long as wide, broadly ovate, thin-textured, scabrous adaxially with sessile stellae with 4-8 appressed lateral rays 0.1-0.4 mm long and erect midpoints 0.2-0.8 mm long, densely stellate pubescent and purple or silvery-gray abaxially; unarmed or sparsely prickly along principal veins; major lateral veins 5-6 on each side; base subcordate or truncate; margin coarsely dentate, with 4-6 deltoid or depressed-deltoid, acute-, obtuse-, or round-tipped lobes at lateral vein terminations, the interlobal sinuses entire or rarely with 1 or 2 smaller tooth-like lobes; apex acute or obtuse; petioles 5-10 (-17) cm, 1/5-1/3 the length of the blades, stellate-pubescent, often sparsely prickly.<br/>Inflorescences 1-4 cm, extra-axillary, often very close to a leaf pair, unbranched, with 15-40 flowers, the distal ones female-sterile, the axes stellate-pubescent, unarmed; peduncle 0.1-0.15 cm; rachis 1-4 cm; pedicels 8-15 mm in flower, often reaching 30 mm in fruit, spaced 0.5-2 apart, articulated at the base.<br/>Flowers with the calyx broadly campanulate, not long enclosing the bud, the radius 9-11 mm, the tube 7-11 mm long, 4-8 mm wide, the lobes 1.5-5 x 4-6 mm, short and broad, rounded or apiculate, rarely ovate, acute-tipped and larger, then approaching or exceeding 1 cm, densely stellate-pubescent abaxially; fruiting calyx somewhat accrescent and the lobes approximately doubling in size. wfo-0001031511	general	"Erect, rhizomatous perennial shrub, 1-2 m high. Juvenile stage unknown. Adult stems white or brown, densely stellate-pubescent, the stellae 0.4-0.7 mm in diameter, the stalks 0-2 mm long, the lateral rays 6-8, porrect, the midpoints eglandular, 2-4 times as long as the lateral rays; finger hairs absent; very short, dense, gland-tipped hairs present; prickles 25-45 per dm, straight, acicular, 4-10 mm long, 9-15 times longer than wide.<br/>Sympodial units plurifoliate, not geminate.<br/>Leaves simple, the blades 4.5-9 (-15) x 2.2-4.3 (-7) cm, 1.7-2.4 times as long as wide, ovate, chartaceous, green and moderately to densely stellate-pubescent adaxially, the hairs spaced 0.3-0.5 mm apart, 0.5-0.9 mm across, the stalks 0-0.3 mm long, the lateral rays 6-9, porrect, the midpoints 2-4 times as long as lateral rays, eglandular; finger hairs absent; very short, gland-tipped hairs present throughout, 0.3-0.8 mm apart; prickles absent or present on midvein only, 0-2, straight, acicular, 5-9 mm long; green and densely stellate-pubescent abaxially, the hairs spaced 0.1-0.2 mm apart, 0.5-0.9 mm diameter, the stalks 0-1.1 mm long, the lateral rays 7-8, porrect, the midpoints 2-3 times as long as lateral rays, eglandular; finger hairs absent; very short, gland-tipped hairs absent; prickles absent; base cuneate to cordate, the oblique part 0-3 mm long; margin entire; apex obtuse or acute; petioles 0.8-2 (-3.5) cm long, 17-25% length of lamina, densely stellate-pubescent, prickles present or absent.<br/>Inflorescence 2-6 cm long, extra-axillary, unbranched, pseudo-racemose, with 5-9 (-12) flowers, the plants strongly andromonoecious, the axes densely stellate-pubescent, armed; peduncle 0.7-2.1 cm long; rachis 0.5-5 cm long; pedicels 10-25 mm long in flower, 0.5-0.7 mm thick throughout, 15-25 mm long in fruit, 1.1-1.6 mm thick at mid-point, nearly contiguous, articulated at the base.<br/>Flowers heterostylous, 5-merous. Calyx 5-15 mm long, the tube 3-5 mm long, the lobes 6-8 (-12) x 2-4 mm, deltate, densely stellate-pubescent with white to brown or rusty hairs, the hairs 0.6-1.5 mm in diameter, the stalks 0.3-1.7 mm long, the lateral rays 5-7, the midpoints 1-3 times as long as the lateral rays, eglandular; finger hairs absent; very short, gland-tipped hairs absent; the prickles on basal bisexual flowers 10-18, 1-7 mm long; prickles absent from distal male flowers; fruiting calyx accrescent, with lobes 10-12 x 5-6 mm, less than to more than half length of mature fruit, the prickles 1-7 mm long. Corolla 2.5-3 (-5) cm in diameter, 9-20 mm long, rotate or shallowly lobed, chartaceous, white, light violet, or purple, the tube ca. 10 mm long, the lobes 8-15 x 5-10 mm, broadly triangular, with ample interpetalar tissue, densely stellate-pubescent on lobe midribs, glabrous to sparsely pubescent on interpetalar tissue abaxially, glabrous adaxially. Stamens with filaments 0.5-1 mm; anthers 4.5-7 x 1-1.5 mm at base, lanceolate, somewhat connivent, yellow, the pores minute and directed distally. Ovary stellate-pubescent; functional style 7-11 x ca. 1 mm, cylindrical, stellate-pubescent, the hairs 0.5-0.9 mm across, the midpoints 2-4 times as long as lateral rays; stigma forked or lobed.<br/>Fruits 1 per inflorescence, 1.8-2.6 cm in diameter, 2-locular, globose or ellipsoidal, orange when ripe, conspicuously tomentose, the exocarp 2.2-3 mm thick, the mesocarp moist but not juicy, the placenta in cross-section stalked, anvil-shaped.<br/>Seeds 2.8-3.5 x 2.5-3 mm, pale yellow, brown or black, discoid, the surface minutely pitted."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-stupefactum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	de5544b0-b8b2-4bc8-8720-09f6378447cf#general	0e339ddc-6633-40da-bcdd-055925f95cd5

wfo-0001026790	distribution	"<p>Ubiquitous weed of low altitudes in southern and eastern Africa from Kenya south to South Africa; growing along roadsides, in abandoned cultivation, savanna, bushland, dunes, and forest edges, and in a wide variety of disturbed habitats; 0-2000 (-2300) m.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-campylacanthum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	19230e27-9dbe-4e03-97ff-59568a98749a#distribution	0e8bfdcf-de64-4277-ad93-2e3ff9bf81b1
wfo-0001026790	general	"Erect shrub, 0.2-1.5(-4) m, prickly or unarmed. Young stems terete, moderately to densely stellate-pubescent and prickly or unarmed, with porrect, sessile or variously stalked trichomes, the stalks to 1.5(2) mm long, the rays 6-12, 0.2-0.4 mm long, the midpoints reduced or up to 0.8 mm, sometimes with minute simple hairs, the prickles 0-5 mm long, 0.2-2 mm wide at base, straight or curved, conical to flattened, pale yellow to orange-brown, glabrous or with a few stellate trichomes near the base, spaced 2-30 mm apart; bark of older stems moderately stellate-pubescent, green-brown to red-brown. <br/>Sympodial units plurifoliate. <br/>Leaves entire, sometimes lobed, the blades 3.5-17(-40) cm long, 0.6-10(-19) cm wide, 1.5-4 times longer than wide, ovate to elliptic or lanceolate, chartaceous, drying concolorous to weakly discolorous, yellow-green to brown-green or red-brown, moderately to densely stellate-pubescent on both surfaces, with porrect, sessile or stalked trichomes, the stalks to 1 mm long, the rays 6-8, 0.2-0.6 mm long, the midpoints ca. same length as the rays or reduced or elongated to 0.8 mm long, sometimes with minute simple hairs, with 0(-2) prickles on both surfaces; the primary veins 4-7 pairs, the tertiary venation usually visible abaxially but not adaxially; base rounded to cordate; margins lobed, the lobes 2-5 on each side, to 1(-3) cm long, extending to 1/4(-1/2) of the distance to the midvein, broad-deltate, apically rounded, sometimes acute; apex rounded to acute; petiole 0.5-4(-11) cm long, 1/6-1/4(-1/3) of the leaf blade length, moderately to densely stellate-pubescent, with 0(-10) prickles.<br/>Inflorescences apparently terminal or lateral, 2-11 cm long, not branched, sometimes branched once, with (2-)5-10(-40) flowers, 1-3(-6) flowers open at any one time, moderately to densely stellate-pubescent, unarmed; peduncle 0-10 mm long; pedicels 0.7-3 cm long in long-styled flowers, 0.5-2 cm long in short-styled flowers, erect, articulated at the base, moderately to densely stellate-pubescent, unarmed; pedicel scars spaced 2-7 mm apart. <br/>. Flowers (4-)5(-6)-merous, heterostylous and the plants andromonoecious, with 1-3(5) long-styled flowers at the base of the inflorescence. Calyx 7-15 mm long in long-styled flowers, 5-10 mm long in short-styled flowers, moderately to densely stellate-pubescent, with 0-20 prickles, the lobes 5-10 mm long in long-styled flowers, 1.5-5 mm long in short-styled flowers, deltate to narrow-deltate, apically acute to obtuse or acuminate. Stamens equal, with the filament tube 2-3 mm long, the free portion of the filaments 0.7-1.5 mm long; anthers 6.5-9 mm long in long-styled flowers, 4-9 mm long in short-styled flowers, connivent, tapering, poricidal at the tips. Ovary glabrous to stellate-pubescent to the upper 1/4, with simple glandular hairs towards the apex; style 1-1.5 cm long in long-styled flowers, stout, straight or gently curved, moderately stellate-pubescent in the lower 1/2-3/4. <br/>Fruit a spherical berry, 1-2(-4) per infructescence, 1.5-3 cm in diameter, the pericarp smooth, dark green with pale green and cream markings when young, yellow at maturity, glabrous; fruiting pedicels 1.5-3 cm long, 1.5-2.5 mm in diameter at base, woody, pendulous, with 0-10 prickles; fruiting calyx lobes elongating to 7-20 mm long, 1/5-1/3 the length of the mature fruit, becoming reflexed, with 0-30 prickles. <br/>Seeds ca. 30-150 per berry, 2.7-3.2 mm long, 1.9-2.6 mm wide, flattened-reniform, dull yellow to orange-brown."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-campylacanthum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	19230e27-9dbe-4e03-97ff-59568a98749a#general	0e8bfdcf-de64-4277-ad93-2e3ff9bf81b1

wfo-0001026262	general	"Scandent shrub to vine 1-4 m. Stems sparsely armed with recurved, tan to brown roselike prickles, these 1-2 mm long, the base 0.5-1.5 x 0.2-0.6 mm, moderately pubescent with tan to rusty, porrect-stellate hairs, the stalks nearly absent to 0.5 mm, multiseriate, the rays 4-8, 0.5-1 mm, unicellular to multicellular, the midpoints nearly absent. <br/>Sympodial units difoliate , the leaves geminate, those of a pair often unequal. <br/>Leaves simple, the blades 4-15 x 2-5 cm, ovate, unlobed, chartaceous, slightly discolorous, dark green adaxially, light green abaxially, the adaxial surface moderately pubescent with stellate hairs like those of the stem but with the midpoints 0.5-1 mm long, the abaxial surface moderately to densely pubescent with hairs like those of the stem; major veins 4-6 on either side of the midvein, the secondary veins obscure, the midrib abaxially with a few recurved prickles like those of the stem; base obtuse, occasionally slightly asymmetrical; apex acute; petioles nearly absent to 1.5 cm, moderately pubescent with hairs like those of the stem, armed with a few prickles like those of the stem. <br/>Inflorescences 3-6 cm, extra-axillary, unbranched, with 4-10 flowers, apparently all perfect, the axes moderately pubescent with hairs like those of the stem, unarmed; peduncle nearly absent to 3 cm; rachis 2-5 cm; pedicels 3-10 mm in flower, 10-15 mm in fruit, filiform, contiguous to very slightly expanded at distal end, spaced 1-5 mm apart. <br/>Flowers apparently all perfect, 5-merous. Calyx 1-2 mm long, the tube 0.5-1mm, the lobes 0.5-1 x 0.25-0.5 mm, triangular, moderately pubescent with hairs like those of the stem, unarmed; fruiting calyx 2-3 mm, not accrescent in fruit. Corolla 7-13 mm in diameter, chartaceous, white, stellate, lobed nearly to the base, lacking interpetelar tissue, the lobes 3-6 x 0.75-1.5 mm, narrowly triangular, moderately pubescent abaxially with stellate hairs like those of the adaxial leaf surface, glabrous adaxially. Stamens 4-7 mm; filaments 1-2 mm, glabrous; anthers 4-6 x 0.8-1.4 mm, attenuate, tapering, connivent, yellow, the base cordate, the apex obtuse, the pores apical, directed slightly intorsely. Ovary glabrous; style 7-9 x 0.5-1 mm, exserted beyond the stamens, cylindrical, white, glabrous; stigma to 1 mm wide, cylindrical, green. <br/>Fruit a berry, 5-8 mm in diameter, globose, green with dark green mottling when immature, orange when mature, glabrous. <br/>Seeds 30 per fruit, 2-2.5 x 1.5-2 mm, reniform, brown, the surface netlike with pits separated by raised ridges."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-apaporanum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	005f6ce5-5903-4a1a-8cc2-2577362aea19#general	0edf9f24-23fc-46cb-8903-05746a383575
wfo-0001028888	distribution	"<p><i>Solanum kurtzianum</i> is found in western and northwestern Argentina (Provs. Mendoza, San Juan, La Rioja and Catamarca), in dry rocky hillsides, desert steppes and among herbs, spiny shrubs and low woods, along streamsides, dry river beds and alluvial cones, (750) 1400-2100 (3000) m in elevation.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-kurtzianum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	fc26f4b1-5a4b-4ffb-8d21-4fd86d941570#distribution	0edfc7f2-7218-45bb-947e-c1d0a4802d09
wfo-0001028888	general	"Herbs 0.15-0.5 m tall, erect. Stems 3-4 mm in diameter at base of plant, green to purple or slightly green and purple mottled, unwinged or with wings less than 1 mm, subglabrous to sparsely covered with short whitish hairs; tubers typically placed one at the end of each stolon.<br/>Sympodial units tri- to plurifoliate, not geminate.<br/>Leaves odd-pinnate, the blades 12.5-25 x 8-13.5 cm, green, often glaucous and with the central midrib purple, membranous to chartaceous, sparsely pubescent to subglabrous adaxially and abaxially with hairs like those of the stems; lateral leaflet pairs 3-4, often subequal except for the most proximal 1-2 pairs that are greatly reduced in size; most distal lateral leaflets 3.8-8.3 x 1.5-4 cm, broadly ovate to broadly elliptic, the apex acute to acuminate, the base typically rounded and oblique; terminal leaflet 3.6-12.5 x 2.3-5 cm, broadly ovate to broadly elliptic, the apex acute to acuminate, the base truncate to cuneate; interjected leaflets 0-7, sessile to short petiolulate, ovate to orbicular, petiolules 0-5 mm; petioles 0-3.5 cm, pubescent as the stems. Pseudostipules 6-11 mm long, pubescent with hairs like those of the stem.<br/>Inflorescences 5-10 cm, terminal with a subtending axillary bud, generally in distal half of the plant, usually forked, with 4-25 flowers, with all flowers apparently perfect, the axes pubescent with hairs like those of the stem; peduncle 2.3-7 cm long; pedicels 10-25 mm long in flower and fruit, spaced 1-10 mm apart, articulated at or below the middle, sometimes low in the proximal half.<br/>Flowers homostylous, 5-merous. Calyx 4-7 mm long, the tube 1-2 mm, the lobes 2-6 mm, acute to apiculate, the acumens 1-3 mm long, pubescent with hairs like those of the stem. Corolla 2.5-3.3 cm in diameter, substellate to pentagonal, white to white with a violet streak in the center of the corolla lobes abaxially and adaxially, the tube 1-2 mm long, the acumens 2-5 mm long, the corolla edges flat, not folded dorsally, glabrous adaxially, minutely puberulent abaxially, especially along the midribs, ciliate at the margins, especially at the tips of the corollas. Stamens with the filaments 1-2 mm long; anthers 5-7 mm long, lanceolate, connivent, yellow, poricidal at the tips, the pores lengthening to slits with age. Ovary glabrous; style 8-11 mm x ca. 1 mm, exceeding stamens by 3-5 mm, straight, glabrous; stigma clavate to capitate.<br/>Fruit a globose berry, 1-1.5 cm in diameter, green when ripe, often with scattered white dots, glabrous.<br/>Seeds from living specimens ovoid and ca. 2 mm long, whitish to greenish in fresh condition and drying brownish, with a thick covering of “hair-like” lateral walls of the testal cells that make the seeds mucilaginous when wet, green-white throughout; testal cells honeycomb-shaped when lateral walls removed by enzyme digestion."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-kurtzianum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	fc26f4b1-5a4b-4ffb-8d21-4fd86d941570#general	0edfc7f2-7218-45bb-947e-c1d0a4802d09

wfo-0001026485	general	"Scandent robust perennial vine. Stems 0.25-1 cm in diameter, sometimes hollow, glabrous to sparsely puberulent with unbranched trichomes; internodes 10-20 cm; prickles 1.5-5 x 2-3 mm at base, straight to recurved.<br/>Sympodial units difoliate, geminate.<br/>Leaves simple and compound, even on the same specimen; simple leaves with blades 4.5-9 x 2.5-5 cm, ca. 2 times as long as wide, ovate; compound leaves imparipinnate, 20-50 x 20-40 cm, ca. 1-1.5 times as long as wide, with 2-4 pairs of subopposite leaflets, the leaflet blades 5-20 x 4-9 cm, ovate to elliptic, subcoriaceous, glabrous adaxially, glabrous to puberulent abaxially, armed with recurved prickles abaxially on midvein; major lateral veins 7-15 on each side; base truncate to acute, oblique; margin entire; apex acute to attenuate; rachis broadly or narrowly winged with tissue like that of leaflets, to 1.5 cm wide, armed below with recurved prickles; petioles 3.5-7 cm, sometimes winged to base, glabrous.<br/>Inflorescences 3-25 (-35) cm, to 45 cm and elongating in fruit, opposite a leaf pair, unbranched or forked, with 10-25 flowers, the plants andromonoecious, with only the lowermost flowers fertile, one fruit developing per inflorescence, the axes glabrous or nearly so, occasionally armed with prickles; peduncle 1-4 cm; rachis 3-6 (-22) cm; pedicels 1-10 mm in flower, 20-30 mm in fruit, spaced 1-2 mm apart, congested toward tip of inflorescence, articulated at or slightly above the base, leaving swollen scars.<br/>Flowers heterostylous, 5-merous. Calyx 6-10 mm in diameter, 3-4 mm long, spreading, the tube 5-7 mm, the lobes 1-2 x 1-2 mm, ovate, acute at apices, glabrous; fruiting calyx accrescent. Corollas 1-2.5 cm in diameter, spreading to reflexed, stellate, chartaceous, greenish-white, the tube 1-2 mm, the lobes 6-10 x 1-2 mm at base, narrowly triangular to lanceolate, acute at apices, glabrous adaxially and abaxially. Stamens with filaments 1-2 mm; anthers 6-9 x 2 mm at base and then tapering, long-attenuate, connivent, yellow, the pores small and directed distally. Ovary sparsely pubescent; style 3-6 x ca. 0.25 mm, cylindrical, straight, glabrous to sparsely puberulent; stigma truncate.<br/>Fruits 2-6 x 3-7 cm, usually globose, rarely obovoid (pyriform), bright orange when ripe, glabrous, the surface appearing rugose when dry. wfo-0001031793	general	"Erect shrub or small tree 2-3 (-4) m tall, sparsely branched. Stems densely pubescent with stellate hairs (sessile or stipitate, porrect stellate with a long central midpoint), the general aspect rusty, armed with scattered prickles 3-8 mm long, these mostly absent on distal branches. <br/>Sympodial units difoliate, usually geminate.<br/>Leaves simple, the blades up to 13-20 x 8-11 cm in larger adult leaves, broadly elliptic, the smaller leaves similar but about 3/4 the size of the larger, chartaceous, both surfaces densely stellate-pubescent with reddish brown (ferrugineous) stellate trichomes similar to those of the stems, the leaves usually unarmed; base rounded to broadly cuneate, very oblique; margin with 2-5 shallow or well-developed lobes on each side, the lobes 1-3 cm long, broadly triangular, their apices obtuse or acute, the sinuses rounded and cut 1/5 to 1/3 way to midrib, the lobing of older or distal leaves reduced; apex acuminate; petioles 1.5-4 cm long, densely stellate-pubescent. Juvenile leaves with blades to ca. 30 x 26 cm, broadly ovate, armed with scattered prickles 3-8 mm long, with 3-4 principal lobes cut 1/3 to 1/4 way to midrib, the lobes to 7 x 4 cm, broadly triangular, the apex acute to obtuse, the sinuses rounded, the main lobes with 1-2 broad shallow lobes; petiole to ca. 11 cm long, armed with scattered prickles 3-8 mm long.<br/>Inflorescence extra-axillary, unbranched, forked, or further branched, with up to 40 flowers, all flowers apparently perfect, the axes densely pubescent with simple and reduced stellate hairs often with glandular tips; peduncle 1-2 cm (some inflorescences with a single flower at extreme base); rachis 1-8 cm; pedicels 10-15 mm long in flower, 15-20 mm long and stout and thickened upwards in fruit, articulated at the base.<br/>Flowers all apparently perfect, 5-merous, homostylous. Calyx tube 2-3 mm long, the lobes 2-3 mm long, triangular with linear acumens 2-5 mm long, densely stellate-pubescent; fruiting calyx accrescent, the lobes ca. 10 mm long, triangular-acuminate. Corolla ca. 2 cm in diameter, white, broadly stellate with abundant interpetalar tissue, the lobes ca. 7 mm long. Stamens with filaments ca. 1.5 mm long; anthers ca. 5 mm long, oblong-lanceolate, porocidal at the tips, the pores not elongating. Ovary ca. 2 mm long, with a few glandular hairs at the apex; style ca. 7 mm long, erect; stigma capitate, minutely bilobed.<br/>Fruit a berry, 1-1.5 cm in diameter, globose, yellow to orange-yellow, aging to brownish or almost black, mucilaginous, up to 20 maturing per inflorescence; fruiting pedicels 1.5-2 cm, woody and erect.<br/>Seeds many per berry, ca. 2 mm long, orbicular-ovate, flattened, yellow-brown, the reticulation of the testa scarcely evident."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-torvoideum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	7e8d88b0-9149-474f-b498-8059f2c8867c#general	0fcdd72b-482e-49e7-81f7-e59d8f0128b6

wfo-0001025856	general	"Vine. Stems perennial, herbaceous to subwoody, 2–4 mm in diameter; internodes 1–5 cm long, glabrescent; prickles always present, stout, to 2 mm long, recurved. <br/>Sympodial units usually plurifoliate, rarely difoliate, not geminate.<br/>Leaves pinnately compound, the blades in outline (5–) 15–20 × (4–) 6–12 cm, ca. 1.4 times as long as wide with 5–7 pairs of opposite to subopposite petiolulate leaflets, chartaceous, glabrous adaxially and abaxially, with calcium oxalate crystals commonly present abaxially and adaxially, often armed on rachis with recurved prickles; major lateral veins 4–6 on each side, corresponding to the leaflets; petioles (1–) 3–5 cm, glabrous, often armed with recurved prickles; leaflets 3-10 × 1-3 cm, oblong to elliptic, widest at the base; base cuneate and oblique; margin entire; apex acuminate; petiolules 0.3-1 cm.<br/>Inflorescences (10–) 20–30 cm long and wide, lateral or terminal, always branched, with 20–35 flowers, the axes glabrous, armed throughout with recurved prickles at base; peduncle (2–) 5–15 cm; rachis 4–10 cm; pedicels 10–15 mm and slender at anthesis, articulated at the base; fruiting pedicels to 20 × 3 mm and becoming subwoody. <br/>Flower buds ellipsoid to somewhat pointed, the corolla soon exserted from the calyx tube. Calyx campanulate, spreading, the tube 2–4 mm, the lobes ca. 3 × 2 mm, rounded, apiculate at tips, glabrous. Corolla 2.5–4 cm in diameter, spreading at anthesis, uniformly white, stellate, lobed ca. 3/4 way to the base, the lobes 1–2 × 0.3–0.5 cm, narrowly triangular, acute to acuminate at apices, glabrous abaxially and adaxially, the tips densely papillate. Stamens 5–10 mm long; filaments unequal, with four 1–1.5 mm long, the fifth 3–4 mm long, glabrous; anthers nearly equal, 5–7 × 1.5–2 mm, the one on the longer filament slightly larger, oblong, connivent, yellow or orange, poricidal at the tips, the pores lengthening to slits with age. Ovary glabrous; style ca. 10 × 0.5 mm in long-styled flowers, straight, glabrous; stigma truncate. <br/>Fruit a globose berry, ca. 3 cm in diameter, green with light green streaks, the pericarp glabrous, rugose when dry. <br/>Seeds ca. 3 × 3 mm, strongly flattened-reniform, light brown, the surface foveolate."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-alternatopinnatum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	8aa724e1-b118-406d-ad84-c24d4e57a33a#general	10506ded-3ae9-4ae7-af64-7e585ea6ebff

wfo-0001027354	general	"Shrubs to small trees, 1-7 m tall; young stems and leaves densely covered with loosely branching golden tree-like trichomes; leaf scars somewhat raised, the stem not winged; bark of older stems dark reddish-brown, sparsely pubescent with the tree-like trichomes of the young stems. New growth densely pubescent with golden tree-like trichomes above and below.<br/>Sympodial units plurifoliate, branching monochasial or dichasial.<br/>Leaves elliptic or occasionally narrowly elliptic (type), 6.5-13 cm x 1.7-5 cm, with 8-12 pairs of secondary veins, the adaxial surfaces of the blades drying dark, sparsely pubescent with golden tree-like trichomes, these mostly along the veins, the abaxial sides pubescent with golden trichomes like those of the adaxial surfaces, the pubescent denser than that above, the apex acute, the base acute, not winged on to the petiole; petiole 0.5-2 cm long, densely golden pubescent.<br/>Inflorescences terminal, later appearing lateral or in the fork of the branches, densely pubescent with loose golden tree-like trichomes like those of the young stems, pyramidal, 4-10 cm long, branching ca. 10 times, with 10-20 flowers. wfo-0001031881	general	"Shrubs or small trees, 1-7 m tall; young stems and leaves glabrous or minutely papillose, soon glabrous; branches erect, green; young leaves pubescent along the midrib beneath; bark of older stems greyish-brown.<br/>Sympodial units difoliate, geminate.<br/>Leaves elliptic to obovate, widest at or just distal to the middle, glabrous above, sparsely to densely pubescent beneath with uniseriate simple or branched trichomes in the axils of the main lateral veins or along the midrib, the trichomes golden and usually branched, 0.5-1 mm long; major leaves 10-30 x 7-14 cm, with 10-12 pairs of main lateral veins, these drying golden brown beneath, the apex acute, the base acute to attenuate; petioles 1.5-2.5 cm long, lightly winged from the decurrent leaf bases; minor leaves differing from the major ones only in size, but occasionally in shape, orbicular to elliptic, 3-19 x 2-9 cm, the apex acute, the base acute to attenuate; petioles 0.4-1 cm long.<br/>Inflorescences opposite the leaves, 1.2-6 cm long, usually branched in the distal 1/3, densely puberulent with erect uniseriate trichomes 0.1-0.5 mm long, these either simple or branched; pedicel scars evenly spaced ca. 0.5 mm apart. Buds globose when very young, the corolla soon exserted, the buds then ellipsoid, densely puberulent. Pedicels at anthesis deflexed, white, 1-1.3 cm long, tapering from the constriction at the base of the calyx tube to a slender base ca. 0.5 mm in diam., sparsely to densely puberulent with trichomes like those of the rest of the inflorescence.<br/>Flowers with the calyx tube broadly campanulate, 1-1.5 mm long, with a strong constriction at the base, this not apparent in dry material, the lobes broadly deltoid with rounded tips, 0.5-1 mm long, with a constriction at the junction of the lobes and the tube, densely golden-puberulent; corolla white, fleshy, 1-1.5 cm in diam., lobed 3/4 of the way to the base, the lobes planar at anthesis, the margins and tips of the lobes densely golden-puberulent like the rest of the inflorescence; anthers 3.5-4 x 1-1.5 mm, poricidal at the tips, the pores tear-drop shaped; free portion of the filaments minute, absent to 0.2 mm long, the filament tube 0.5-0.7 mm long; ovary densely golden-pubescent, the trichomes uniseriate, simple or branched, 0.2-0.6 mm long; style straight, 5-6 mm long, pubescent at the base; stigma capitate, the surface minutely papillose.<br/>Fruit a globose, green, 1-1.5 cm in diam.; fruiting pedicels woody, erect or slightly deflexed at fruit maturity, 1-1.5 cm long, ca. 1 mm in diam. at the base.<br/>Seeds dark brown in dry material, ovoid-reniform, ca. 2.5 x 2 mm, the margins somewhat incrassate, the surfaces minutely pitted."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-triste		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	ffe2b2e2-f0fa-4cdd-8dae-a2b03762086c#general	10b78e93-cd1d-4d94-81e7-9be117b3950b
wfo-0001027583	conservation	"<p>The calculations of extent of occurrence (ca. 760,000 km<sup>2</sup>) and area of occupancy (1,744 km<sup>2</sup>) for Solanum dimidiatum were based on its estimated native distribution (i.e., Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Arkansas, Missouri, and Kansas) and excluded the outlying occurrences in Illinois, New Mexico, South Carolina, and Mexico. Given its weedy habit and preference for disturbed habitats, S. dimidiatum is assigned a preliminary conservation status of ""least concern"" (LC).</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-dimidiatum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	5ba919cb-c2f8-4da3-b5c4-746be6a82438#conservation	10fd19c7-9fd2-490e-9f78-8a7ae6588519
wfo-0001027583	distribution	"<p>Solanum dimidiatum is distributed in Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Arkansas, Missouri, and Kansas with a few outlier populations in Illinois, New Mexico, South Carolina, and Mexico. Its native distribution prior to European settlement is not known with certainty because of its weedy, invasive nature and ability to colonize disturbed habitats. It can become a noxious weed locally and has the potential to establish reproducing populations when introduced into suitable habitats. It has been introduced in California and in Australia, but apparently has been successfully eradicated in both areas (Jepson Flora Project 2014; eFloraSA 2014). The California Department of Food and Agriculture rates S. dimidiatum under category 'A' as ""a pest of known...environmental detriment"" (CDFA 2014). It grows in prairies and oak woodlands as well as disturbed areas such as roadsides, grazed and mowed pastures, ditches, cultivated and urban waste areas, and railroad rights of way in sandy soils or on a variety of other soil types at elevations from 200–600 m.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-dimidiatum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	5ba919cb-c2f8-4da3-b5c4-746be6a82438#distribution	10fd19c7-9fd2-490e-9f78-8a7ae6588519
wfo-0001027583	use	"<p>Three common names widely used are Torrey's horsenettle, western horsenettle, and robust horsenettle. Jordan et al. (2006) report that the Plains Apache Native Americans may have utilized the fruits of S. dimidiatum in some aspects of their material culture; however, all parts of the plant are considered poisonous to humans and livestock. In cattle, it is known to cause ""crazy cow syndrome,"" a debilitating disease caused by the calystegine alkaloids present in this species (Menzies et al. 1979; Anderson 2002).</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-dimidiatum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Use	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	5ba919cb-c2f8-4da3-b5c4-746be6a82438#use	10fd19c7-9fd2-490e-9f78-8a7ae6588519
wfo-0001027742	distribution	"<p><i>Solanum echinatum</i> is common in the Northern Territory and is found in the northwestern corner of Queensland, Australia. In Queensland it occurs as far south as Mt. Isa, and in the Northern Territory it also occurs on the islands of the Gulf of Carpentaria. It also occurs in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. It grows on stony ridges or gullies in low eucalypt woodland, on a variety of substrates, including laterite.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-echinatum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	b907bb5b-caa2-4aa6-9947-a65d98985bf2#distribution	11150969-af5e-48db-a44b-f8218087068c
wfo-0001027742	general	"Erect or prostrate, rhizomatous annual or perennial shrub, 0.1-0.5 m tall. Juvenile stage unknown. Adult stems yellow, rusty or brown, very densely stellate-pubescent, the stellae 0.6-0.8 mm in diameter, the stalks 0-0.8 mm long, the lateral rays 7-8, porrect, the midpoints 0.8-1.8 times as long as lateral rays, eglandular; finger hairs absent; very short, gland-tipped hairs absent; prickles 1-8 mm long, straight, acicular, 10-20 times longer than wide, with 200-660 prickles per decimetre.<br/>Sympodial units 2-foliate, geminate.<br/>Leaves simple, the blades (2-) 3.5-9.5 (-13) x (1-) 2-5.5 (-9) cm, 1.7-2 times as long as wide, ovate to ovate-lancelate, chartaceous, grey-green and moderately to densely stellate-pubescent adaxially, the hairs distributed throughout, spaced 0.1-0.4 mm apart, 0.4-0.8 mm in diameter, the stalks 0-0.2 mm long, the lateral rays 7-9, porrect, the midpoints 1-1.5 times as long as lateral rays, eglandular; finger hairs absent; very short, gland-tipped hairs absent; prickles absent or present on midvein only or present on midvein and lateral veins, 0-12, 3-5 mm long, straight, acicular; white or yellowish and densely to very densely stellate-pubescent abaxially, the hairs spaced 0.05-0.1 mm apart, 0.6-0.9 mm in diameter, the stalks 0-0.2 mm long, the lateral rays 7-8, porrect, the midpoints 1-1.5 times as long as lateral rays, eglandular; finger hairs absent; very short, gland-tipped hairs absent; prickles absent or present on midvein only or present on midvein and lateral veins, 0-9, straight, acicular; base obtuse or cordate, oblique part 0-3.5 mm long; margin entire or shallowly lobed throughout, the lobes 3-4 on each side, obtuse, lobing index 1-1.1; apex acute; petioles 0.5-5 cm long, 25-55% length of lamina, very densely stellate-pubescent, prickles present.<br/>Inflorescence 3.5-10 cm, extra-axillary, unbranched, pseudo-racemose, with 2-5 (-8) flowers, with all flowers perfect, the axes very densely stellate-pubescent, armed; peduncle 2.5-5 cm; rachis 1-5 cm; pedicels 3-9 (-20) mm long in flower, 1-1.2 mm thick at mid-point, the same thickness throughout or markedly thicker distally, 10-18 mm long in fruit, 1-1.8 mm thick at mid-point, articulated at the base.<br/>Flowers homostylous, 5-merous. Calyx 5-12 mm, the tube 3-6 mm long, the lobes 2-6 mm long, rostrate or attenuate, very densely stellate-pubescent, the hairs yellow, brown or rusty, 0.7-0.9 mm in diameter, the stalks 0-1.1 mm long, the lateral rays 7-8, the midpoints 1-1.8 times as long as lateral rays, eglandular; finger hairs absent; very short, gland-tipped hairs absent; prickles present at anthesis, 60-300 per flower, 1-3 mm long; fruiting calyx tube accrescent, enclosing most or all of mature fruit, prickles 1-8 mm long. Corolla 2-3 cm in diameter, 9-14 mm long, broadly stellate-pentagonal, chartaceous, lilac or purple, the lobes broad and rounded, with abundant interpetalar tissue, the lobe tips exceeding the interpetalar tissue, glabrous adaxially. Stamens with filaments 1-2 mm; anthers 4-6 mm long, lanceolate, loosely connivent, yellow, the pores minute and directed distally. Ovary glabrous; style 7-10 mm, cylindrical, slightly or strongly curved and bent to one side outside the anther cone, glabrous; stigma truncate to capitate.<br/>Fruits 1-4 per inflorescence, 1-2 cm in diameter, 4-locular, depressed globose, somewhat square or 4-lobed, pale ivory-green or yellowish-green, finally drying brown, glabrous, the mesocarp moist but not juicy, the exocarp 2-2.3 mm thick, the placenta in cross-section stalked, anvil-shaped.<br/>Seeds 2-2.5 mm long, brown to black, the surface minutely reticulate, especially toward margins."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-echinatum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	b907bb5b-caa2-4aa6-9947-a65d98985bf2#general	11150969-af5e-48db-a44b-f8218087068c

wfo-0001027010	general	"Herbs 0.5-1.5 m tall, erect. Stems 3-8 mm in diameter at base of plant, green, sometimes with purple spots, sometimes winged with very narrow wings 0-2.5 mm long, glabrous or glabrescent with short and acute hairs; tubers typically moniliform (multiple tubers arranged along the stolon like beads on a necklace).<br/>Sympodial units tri- to plurifoliate, not geminate.<br/>Leaves odd-pinnate, the blades 4.9-31 x 4.4-29 cm, usually light green abaxially, sometimes with some light purple coloration, usually deep green adaxially, coriaceous and scabrous, usually glabrous to glabrescent with white short hairs adaxially, glabrous to glabrescent with short hairs abaxially; lateral leaflet pairs 1-4, usually decreasing in size toward the leaf base, with the terminal leaflet generally subequal to the laterals or slightly larger; most distal lateral leaflets 3.5-13.6 x 1.4-6.9 cm, ovate to elliptic, the apex acute to acuminate, the base petiolulate or sessile and attenuate to rounded, asymmetric with more tissue on the basiscopic side; terminal leaflet 2.1-15.3 x 2-9.4 cm, ovate to elliptic, the apex acute to acuminate, the base usually attenuate; interjected leaflets 0-2, sessile to short petiolulate, ovate to orbicular; petioles 0.4-5.1 cm, glabrous to glabrescent. Pseudostipules when present 1-10 mm long, glabrous to glabrescent.<br/>Inflorescences 4-12 cm, terminal with a subtending axillary bud, generally in distal half of the plant, usually forked, with 10-60 flowers, with all flowers apparently perfect, the axes glabrous or glabrescent with short white hairs; peduncle 2.2-12.9 cm long; pedicels 14-46 mm long in flower and fruit, spaced 3-5 mm apart, articulated high in the distal half.<br/>Flowers homostylous, 5-merous. Calyx 5-13 mm long, the tube 3-6 mm, the lobes 5-14 mm, ovate to lanceolate, with acumens 1-7 mm long, usually glabrous. Corolla 2.1-4.3 cm in diameter, pentagonal to rotate, white to purple, the tube 1-2 mm long, the acumens 0-3 mm long, the corolla edges flat, not folded dorsally, usually glabrous abaxially and adaxially. Stamens with the filaments 1-2 mm long; anthers 4-8 mm long, lanceolate, connivent, yellow, poricidal at the tips, the pores lengthening to slits with age. Ovary glabrous; style 3-10 mm x ca. 1 mm, exceeding stamens by 2-6 mm, straight, glabrous; stigma clavate to capitate.<br/>Fruits ovoid, 1.2-1.7 cm wide, 1.2-1.9 cm long, usually light green with deep green stripes when ripe, glabrous, occasionally scabrous.<br/>Seeds from living specimens ovoid and ca. 2 mm long, whitish to greenish in fresh condition and drying brownish, with a thick covering of “hair-like” lateral walls of the testal cells that make the seeds mucilaginous when wet, green-white throughout; testal cells honeycomb-shaped when lateral walls removed by enzyme digestion."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-chiquidenum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	fcb12c01-496c-4bb1-89e8-a729fe107320#general	11c84de0-c993-4225-aa5c-498a2c637e50

Buds ellipsoid, the tips flattened, exserted from the calyx tubes, but not exceeding the lobes. Pedicels at anthesis slender, nodding, 3-6 mm long, ca. 0.5 mm in diam., densely pubescent with dendritic trichomes like those of the rest of the inflorescence.<br/>Flowers with the calyx tube conical, 1-1.5 mm long, the lobes long-triangular with rounded apices, 2-2.5 mm long, pubescent with dendritic trichomes 0.5-1 mm long; corolla white (?), 1-1.1 cm in diam., lobed nearly to the base, the lobes planar at anthesis, the tips and margins densely papillose; anthers 2-2.5 x 1-1.5 mm, poricidal at the tips, the pores tear-drop shaped; free portion of the filaments ca. 0.5 mm long, the filament tube ca. 0.5 mm long, glabrous; ovary glabrous; style straight, ca. 5 mm long, sparsely pubescent with simple trichomes ca. 0.3 mm long; stigma small-capitate, the surface minutely papillose.<br/>Fruit a globose, red or orange-red berry, the pericarp thin and shiny, 1-1.5 cm in diam.; fruiting pedicels woody, erect, ca. 1 cm long, 0.7-1 mm in diam.<br/>Seeds pale tan, flattened-reniform with incrassate margins, 2-2.5 x 1.5-2 mm, the surfaces minutely pitted, the cells rectangular in outline."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-spissifolium		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	48c0bfc1-96ca-4106-bf13-ccaaa9a93b89#general	1201175e-6328-4c70-a9b2-58d562f608a7
wfo-0001025760	distribution	"<p>Cultivated throughout tropical Sub-Saharan Africa and on Madagascar, not known in the wild except as feral individuals; also cultivated in South America and in some parts of Europe and Asia; thrives in full sun and woodland savannah.  In temperate zones cultivars apparently cannot tolerate cold or wet conditions and are only grown in greenhouse conditions or in the summer.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-aethiopicum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	fd2b4df6-6f03-4c64-82d4-6f3da57f581f#distribution	1221a23d-f624-4be1-b98e-49011a9c6c51
wfo-0001025760	general	"Erect annual or perennial herb to shrub, 0.3-1 m, unarmed. Young stems terete, glabrous to moderately stellate-pubescent and unarmed, with porrect, sessile or variously stalked trichomes, the stalks to 0.1 mm long, the rays ca. 8(-12), 0.15-0.3 mm long, the midpoints shorter than the rays, often with minute simple hairs; bark of older stems glabrous, sometimes glabrescent, orange to dark brown.<br/>Sympodial units difoliate, geminate or not geminate.<br/>Leaves subentire to weakly lobed, the blades 5-18 cm long, 2.5-10 cm wide, 2-3 times longer than wide, ovate, sometimes elliptic, membranous to chartaceous, drying concolorous to discolorous, yellow-green to dark red-brown or almost black; adaxial surface glabrous to moderately stellate-pubescent, with thick-stalked trichomes; abaxial surface glabrous to moderately stellate-pubescent with porrect, sessile or stalked trichomes, the stalks to 0.1 mm long, the rays ca. 8(-12), 0.2-0.35 mm long, the midpoints shorter than the rays, often with minute simple hairs; the primary veins 3-6 pairs, the tertiary venation usually visible on both surfaces; base cuneate to rounded; margins lobed, the lobes to 3 on each side, up to 1.5 cm long, extending up to 1/4 of the distance to the midvein, broad-deltate, apically rounded, sometimes acute; apex acute; petiole 1-4 cm long, 1/4-1/3 of the leaf blade length, glabrous to moderately stellate-pubescent. <br/>Inflorescences apparently lateral, 1-1.8 cm long, unbranched, with 1-2(-10) flowers, 1(-3) flowers open at any one time, glabrous to moderately stellate-pubescent; peduncle 0-0.5 mm long; pedicels 0.5-2 cm long, gently curved, articulated at the base, glabrous to moderately stellate-pubescent; pedicel scars spaced ca. 2 mm apart.<br/>Flowers 5-10-merous, apparently all perfect. Calyx 3.5-9 mm long, glabrous to moderately stellate-pubescent, unarmed, the lobes 1.5-5 mm long, broad-deltate, apically acute. Corolla 0.8-1.8 cm in diameter, white, stellate, lobed for ca. 2/3 of the way to the base, the lobes 2.5-8 mm long, 1.5-4.5 mm wide, deltate, spreading, glabrous to moderately stellate-pubescent abaxially, the trichomes porrect, sessile or stalked, the stalks up to 0.1 mm long, the rays 8-10(-12), 0.1-0.2 mm long, the midpoints shorter than the rays. Stamens equal, with the filament tube ca. 1.5 mm long, the free portion of the filaments 0.4-0.8 mm long; anthers 2.3-4(-6) mm long, connivent to spreading, tapering, poricidal at the tips. Ovary glabrous or stellate-pubescent in the upper 1/5; style 0.45-0.9 cm long, slender to stout, straight to recurved, glabrous to stellate-pubescent for up to 2/3 of its length.<br/>Fruit a berry, usually spherical but with cultivars of various shapes, 1-4 per infructescence, (1-)1.5-2.5(-5) cm in diameter, the pericarp smooth, dark green with pale green and cream markings when young, orange at maturity, glabrous; fruiting pedicels 0.7-2.5 cm long, 0.5-1.5 mm in diameter at base, woody, erect to pendulous; fruiting calyx lobes elongating to 3.5-17 mm long, 1/4-1/2 the length of the mature fruit, reflexed.<br/>Seeds ca. 20-100 per berry, 2.1-3.5 mm long, 2-2.5 mm wide, flattened-reniform, dull yellow to orange-brown."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-aethiopicum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	fd2b4df6-6f03-4c64-82d4-6f3da57f581f#general	1221a23d-f624-4be1-b98e-49011a9c6c51
wfo-0001025760	use	"<p>Local Names. Scarlet eggplant, African eggplant, bitter tomato (English), Aubergine écarlate, aubergine africaine, tomate amère (French), Jiló (Portuguese), Ngogwe, Nyanya chugu (Swahili). Other names cited on herbarium labels include Nguejio (Cameroon), Suma, Ngago, Teno, Daa-teno (Central African Republic), Nakatti Nakasugga, Omutonga (Uganda), Chipilinganya, Impwa (Zambia).</p><br/><p>Uses. An important traditional garden vegetable used for its edible fruits and leaves, depending upon the cultivar used (see commentary). Medicinal applications include the use of roots and fruits as a carminative, sedative, and to treat colic; leaf juice to treat uterine complains; an alcoholic extract of leaves as a sedative, antiemetic and to treat tetanus after abortion; and crushed and macerated fruits as an enema. Used as a rootstock for eggplant (S. melongena) in Japan, and in eggplant breeding due to its disease resistance.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-aethiopicum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Use	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	fd2b4df6-6f03-4c64-82d4-6f3da57f581f#use	1221a23d-f624-4be1-b98e-49011a9c6c51
wfo-0001026388	distribution	"<p>An often common weedy shrub within forests or more commonly at edges, in second growth, clearings, roadsides, pastures and cultivated ground, at elevations of 1500 to 1900 m in Colombia but below 1000 m in its native range in southeastern Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay and northeastern Argentina. A range map is given in Nee (1979).</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-atropurpureum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	77ab6941-924d-463d-bc52-1c7c2afdf6b7#distribution	12786ab2-2817-4d71-8aa3-ae318e67f05f
wfo-0001026388	general	"Erect shrubs 0.5–2 m tall. Stems to ca. 1.5 cm in diameter, usually with a single stem from the base, the first branches strongly ascending, the upper flowering branches more spreading, the whole plant (exclusive of the flowers) often strongly purple-colored, the prickles sometimes in life (and always when dried) bleaching to a straw color, glabrous except for ± dense covering of minute stipitate glands less than 0.15 mm long, these giving the plant a golden glistening appearance when viewed closely in bright sunlight; stem prickles abundant, straight, acicular, somewhat reflexed, often up to 45?, especially on the lower stem, of various lengths, 0.2–2 cm long and up to 1.6 mm wide at the base, with scattered minute stipitate glands on the lower part.<br/>Sympodial units 2-foliate, usually geminate.<br/>Leaves simple, the blades 5–20 x 20– 45 cm, usually geminate with one about twice the size of the other, ovate to suborbicular, thin-textured, glabrous adaxially or sparsely to moderately pilose with 2–4-celled simple hyaline hairs 1–2 mm long, abaxially sometimes glabrous or with scattered sessile 4–5-rayed stellae 0.8–1.5 mm wide, these mostly confined to between the midrib and the sinuses, armed adaxially and abaxially with prickles on major veins similar to those of petiole in size and shape, grading down to minute ones on the smaller veins; base usually truncate, sometimes oblique; margin shallowly to deeply lobed with 2–4 pairs of acute to acuminate lobes, these ranging from entire and triangular to sinuate or again lobed, the least lobed leaves plane, the most lobed ones with conduplicate divisions and then becoming much folded and twisted in pressing, ciliate with hairs similar to those of the blades; apex attenuate; larger petioles 2–9 cm, with minute stipitate glands, otherwise glabrous or sometimes very sparsely pilose with 4–6-celled spreading hyaline hairs 1.5–3.5 mm long, with 5–20 straight acicular spreading prickles up to 25 long and 3 mm wide at base, similar to but mostly larger than those of the stem, with a few minute stipitate glands. <br/>Inflorescences 0.8–2.5 cm, extra-axillary, unbranched, with 4–10 flowers, with 1–6 (–8) fruits developing, glabrous except for minute stipitate glands; peduncles 0.4–1 cm in flower, 0.5–1.7 cm in fruit, unarmed or with a few straight spreading acicular prickles up to 6 mm long; rachis 0.2–1 cm; pedicels 5–12 mm in flower, 10–20 mm in fruit, somewhat dilated at the apex, sparsely to moderately armed with straight acicular prickles to 3 mm long from a slightly enlarged base, pointing forward at a ca. 45? angle, spaced 0.5–4 mm apart.<br/>Flowers with the calyx ca. 3.5 mm long, divided halfway to base, the tube 1–2.5 mm, the lobes 1-2 x 1-2 mm, triangular or ovate-apiculate, the tips green and thickened, the lateral margins somewhat scarious, ca. 2 x 1.8 mm in fruit, with the scarious margins more apparent, glabrous or nearly so (rarely with one to a few unicellular hairs), unarmed or with a few acicular prickles up to 3 mm long. Corolla 1.5-2 cm in diameter, 8-13 mm long, stellate, thin-textured, variously reported as yellow, greenish, yellow-green or white, probably always a yellowish green, the tube 1.5–2.2 mm, the lobes 6–11 x 2.5–4 mm, lanceolate, acuminate, not apiculate, spreading, the tips recurved, glabrous abaxially and adaxially. Stamens with filaments 1.6 mm, inserted about halfway up the corolla tube; anthers 6–7 x 1.8 mm, attenuate, free, yellow-orange on the outside at the base, much lighter yellowish on the inside and at the tip, the pores small and directed distally. Ovary 1.4 x 1.6 mm, glabrous, white; style 8.5 x 0.2-0.6 mm, exceeding the stamens by ca. 1.2 mm, often turning sideways and exserted between the tips of two anthers, cylindrical, glabrous; stigma truncate, distinctly bilobed, light green, minutely papillate.<br/>Fruit 1.4–1.6 cm in diameter, globose, yellow-orange, glabrous, the surface glutinous when ripe.<br/>Seeds 65–145 per fruit (x = 108, n = 12), 3.2–3.7 mm in diameter, brown, glutinous in ripe fruit, the wing ca. 0.7 mm wide."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-atropurpureum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	77ab6941-924d-463d-bc52-1c7c2afdf6b7#general	12786ab2-2817-4d71-8aa3-ae318e67f05f

wfo-0001028690	distribution	"<p><i>Solanum intonsum</i> is endemic to Queensland. It range is currently known to extend from Cape Melville to just south of Cairns, and west to Mt. Mulligan. There is also an historical record from the Stewart River near Coen. wfo-0001026818	distribution	"<p>A low to middle elevation species encountered from sea level to about 1500 m, occurring naturally in open woodlands and thickets and in light gaps near watercourses in quebradas and barrancas; in partial shade or open sun; versatile in soil tolerance, on both limestone and granite derived soils of diverse textures; in seasonally dry to relatively wet situations; commonly occuring as a successional species in human clearings and disturbances. Extending from barranca woodlands and oak forests of southern Sonora and Chihuahua in Mexico south along the Sierra Madre Occidental to central Mexico, widespread and common in Southern Mexico, Guatemala and El Salvador, apparently less abundant in the remainder of Central America, also in the Chocó of Colombia and lowlands of Ecuador and northern Peru.</p>"		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-candidum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	abd56c80-d214-4de7-907e-9a63726703f6#distribution	12ce283d-69f2-4852-a51a-1e4bf05b3d2b
wfo-0001026818	general	"Erect or spreadingly branched, large-leaved, lignescent perennials, 0.7-2 (-3) m tall. Young stems densely pubescent with a mixture of stipitate to essentially sessile stellate trichomes, the multiseriate stalks of stipitate cauline stellae variable in length, the longest 0.3-2.5 (-4.5) mm, with lateral rays 6-10, 0.3-1 (-1.5) mm long, weakly ascending, the midpoints about equaling the rays in length, occasionally capitate-glandular; cauline prickles variable in size and density, but nearly always abundant, the largest 5-12 mm long, usually somewhat broad-based and laterally compressed.<br/>Sympodial units 2-foliate, geminate or not.<br/>Leaves simple, the blades 7-50 x 7-30 cm, ca. 1-2 times as long as wide, broadly elliptic or elliptic-ovate, thin-textured, pubescent adaxially with sessile stellae, the largest commonly with prominent midpoints 0.5-1.5 (-2.5) mm long and with 4-7 shorter, ascending lateral rays 0.3-0.8 mm long, the larger stellae grading into smaller ones, this transition sometimes abrupt and two distinct size classes of trichomes apparent, densely felty-pubescent abaxially with stalked and sessile stellae similar to those of the stem but the stalked ones on the average shorter, the foliar pubescence in vivo often with a purplish cast, especially along veins; usually prickly, with prickles similar to those of the stem but usually somewhat larger and often more broad-based, scattered along petiole, midrib and principal lateral veins; major lateral veins 4-6 on each side; base truncate to shallowly cordate, sometimes oblique; margin coarsely dentate with 3-5 (-7) deltoid or depressed-deltoid, acute-, obtuse-, or round-tipped lobes at lateral vein terminations, the interlobal sinuses entire or occasionally with 1 or 2 smaller tooth-like lobes; apex acute or obtuse; petioles ca. 3-15 cm, densely pubescent with hairs and prickles like those of the stem.<br/>Inflorescences 0.5-2.5 cm, extra-axillary or leaf-opposed, unbranched, with 5-20 flowers, the distal 1/3 female-sterile, the axes densely stellate-pubescent, usually minutely prickly; peduncle 0-1 cm; rachis 0-1.5 cm; pedicels 5-15 mm long in flower, 7-15 mm and thickened in fruit, spaced closely spaced 0-1 mm apart, articulated at the base.<br/>Flowers with the calyx broadly campanulate, the radius 8-15 mm, the tube 5-11 mm, the lobes 4-10 x 3-5 mm, broadly ovate or deltoid, densely felty-pubescent abaxially with stellate hairs, unarmed; fruiting calyx somewhat accrescent but not covering fruit. Corolla 2.5-4 cm in diameter, ca. 12-15 mm long, stellate, the tube 2-3 mm, thin-textured, white, the lobes 8-15 x 5-9 mm, ovate-lanceolate, spreading, stellate-pubescent abaxially, glabrous adaxially. Stamens with filaments ca. 1 mm; anthers 6.5-9.5 x 1.8-3.5 mm at base, lanceolate, attenuate, more or less connivent, yellow, the pores directed distally. Ovary densely stellate-pubescent; style 8-11 x 0.5-1 mm in perfect flowers, cylindrical, glabrous or sparsely pubescent below the middle; stigma truncate to capitate.<br/>Fruits 1-4 per inflorescence, 2-4.5 cm in diameter, globose, orange or orange-red when ripe, the mesocarp cream or yellowish, densely spreading-hirsute with sessile stellate hairs with elongate midpoints (1.5-) 2.5-5 mm long, the lateral rays 5-15, short, 0.1-0.3 mm, inserted at trichome base, these mostly persistent but sometimes becoming sparse at maturity.<br/>Seeds numerous, 2.7-4 x 2-4 mm, yellow or tan, lenticular, broadly reniform-ovate in outline, the surfaces minutely pitted."		http://solanaceaesource.org/content/solanum-candidum		Solanaceae Source	eng	http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription	text/html	http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text	4370f824-74f6-4245-841d-2954ff554e63	http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/	abd56c80-d214-4de7-907e-9a63726703f6#general	12ce283d-69f2-4852-a51a-1e4bf05b3d2b
